kimpimāya.comments: The word 'kimpimāya' is a sandhi compound formed from 'kiṃ' (what?), 'api' (even), and 'imāya' (this). In the given context, it is used to express a rhetorical question emphasizing 'anything at all'.
kimpimāya.translation_1: Is there anything she would not give?”

succhavilomajāto.meaning_2: perfectly covered with skin and hairs; having soft skin and hair
succhavilomajāto.comments: The compound describes the state of the healed wound, now covered with soft skin and hair, indicating complete healing.
succhavilomajāto.example_1: Tassā saha dassanena bhagavato tāva mahāvaṇo ruḷho ahosi succhavilomajāto.
succhavilomajāto.translation_1: The moment Suppiyā saw the Buddha that great wound healed and was perfectly covered with skin and hairs.

hatthimaṃsādipaṭikkhepakathā.meaning_2: discussion of the prohibition against elephant meat, etc.
hatthimaṃsādipaṭikkhepakathā.comments: The compound is a discussion (kathā) about the prohibition (paṭikkhepa) against elephant meat (hatthimaṃsa) and other things (ādi). It is a feminine compound noun.
hatthimaṃsādipaṭikkhepakathā.translation_1: 10. Discussion of the prohibition against elephant meat, etc.

hatthimaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: elephant meat; flesh of an elephant
hatthimaṃsaṃ.comments: The compound 'hatthimaṃsaṃ' is formed from 'hatthi' (elephant) and 'maṃsa' (meat/flesh), referring specifically to the meat of an elephant. The context shows it was consumed during a food shortage and given to monks.
hatthimaṃsaṃ.example_1: Manussā dubbhikkhe hatthimaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ hatthimaṁsaṁ denti.
hatthimaṃsaṃ.translation_1: Because there was a shortage of food, people ate the elephant meat. They also gave elephant meat to monks who were walking for alms.
hatthimaṃsaṃ.example_2: Manussā dubbhikkhe hatthimaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ hatthimaṁsaṁ denti.
hatthimaṃsaṃ.translation_2: Because there was a shortage of food, people ate the elephant meat. They also gave elephant meat to monks who were walking for alms.

assamaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: horse meat; flesh of a horse
assamaṃsaṃ.comments: The compound 'assamaṃsaṃ' is clearly used in the context of eating horse meat during a famine, indicating it refers specifically to the flesh of a horse. The construction follows the typical Pāḷi compound pattern where the first element (assa) modifies the second (maṃsaṃ).
assamaṃsaṃ.example_1: Manussā dubbhikkhe assamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ assamaṁsaṁ denti.
assamaṃsaṃ.translation_1: Because there was a shortage of food, people ate the horse meat. They also gave horse meat to monks who were walking for alms.
assamaṃsaṃ.example_2: Manussā dubbhikkhe assamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ assamaṁsaṁ denti.
assamaṃsaṃ.translation_2: Because there was a shortage of food, people ate the horse meat. They also gave horse meat to monks who were walking for alms.

sunakhamaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: dog meat; flesh of a dog
sunakhamaṃsaṃ.comments: The compound 'sunakhamaṃsa' is formed by combining 'sunakha' (dog) and 'maṃsa' (meat/flesh), referring specifically to dog meat. In the given context, it is clear that this term is used to describe a type of meat consumed during a famine, highlighting the severity of the food shortage.
sunakhamaṃsaṃ.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena manussā dubbhikkhe sunakhamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ sunakhamaṁsaṁ denti.
sunakhamaṃsaṃ.translation_1: At one time when there was a shortage of food, people ate dog meat. They also gave dog meat to monks who were walking for alms.
sunakhamaṃsaṃ.example_2: Tena kho pana samayena manussā dubbhikkhe sunakhamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ sunakhamaṁsaṁ denti.
sunakhamaṃsaṃ.translation_2: At one time when there was a shortage of food, people ate dog meat. They also gave dog meat to monks who were walking for alms.

ahimaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: snake meat; flesh of a snake
ahimaṃsaṃ.comments: The compound 'ahimaṃsaṃ' is formed from 'ahi' (snake) and 'maṃsa' (meat/flesh), referring specifically to snake meat. The context shows it was consumed during a food shortage and given to monks, though later prohibited.
ahimaṃsaṃ.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena manussā dubbhikkhe ahimaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ ahimaṁsaṁ denti.
ahimaṃsaṃ.translation_1: At one time when there was a shortage of food, people ate snake meat. They also gave snake meat to monks who were walking for alms.
ahimaṃsaṃ.example_2: Tena kho pana samayena manussā dubbhikkhe ahimaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ ahimaṁsaṁ denti.
ahimaṃsaṃ.translation_2: At one time when there was a shortage of food, people ate snake meat. They also gave snake meat to monks who were walking for alms.

sīhamaṃsagandhena.meaning_2: smell of lion's meat; scent of lion's flesh
sīhamaṃsagandhena.comments: The compound 'sīhamaṃsagandha' is a tatpurusa (determinative) compound where 'sīha' (lion) modifies 'maṃsa' (meat), and the resulting 'sīhamaṃsa' (lion's meat) further modifies 'gandha' (smell). The contextual meaning is clearly 'smell of lion's meat', as the sentence describes lions attacking due to this smell.
sīhamaṃsagandhena.translation_1: And because of the smell of lion meat, lions attacked them.

taracchamaṃsaṃ.meaning_2: hyena meat; flesh of a hyena
taracchamaṃsaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'taraccha' (hyena) and 'maṃsa' (meat), referring specifically to the meat of a hyena. It is neuter in gender and follows the a-stem declension pattern for neuter nouns.
taracchamaṃsaṃ.example_1: taracchaṁ hantvā taracchamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ taracchamaṁsaṁ denti.
taracchamaṃsaṃ.translation_1: a hyena and ate the hyena meat. They also gave hyena meat to monks who were walking for alms.
taracchamaṃsaṃ.example_2: taracchaṁ hantvā taracchamaṁsaṁ paribhuñjanti, bhikkhūnaṁ piṇḍāya carantānaṁ taracchamaṁsaṁ denti.
taracchamaṃsaṃ.translation_2: a hyena and ate the hyena meat. They also gave hyena meat to monks who were walking for alms.

taracchamaṃsagandhena.comments: The compound 'taracchamaṃsagandha' is a tatpurusa compound (determinative compound) where 'gandha' (smell) is the final element, modified by 'taracchamaṃsa' (hyena meat). The meaning in context refers specifically to the smell emanating from hyena meat, which caused the hyenas to attack.
taracchamaṃsagandhena.translation_1: And because of the smell of hyena meat, hyenas attacked them.

suppiyabhāṇavāro.comments: The compound refers to a specific section of scripture for recitation related to Suppiyā. The context shows it's the second such section.
suppiyabhāṇavāro.translation_1: The second section for recitation on Suppiyā is finished.

yāgumadhugoḷakānujānana.grammar: fem, comp, abstr, act, from anujānāti
yāgumadhugoḷakānujānana.meaning_2: the allowance for congee and honey balls; permission for rice gruel and honey sweets
yāgumadhugoḷakānujānana.comments: This is a compound word consisting of three parts: 'yāgu' (rice gruel), 'madhugoḷaka' (honey balls), and 'anujānana' (allowance). The context is from the Vinaya, referring to a specific permission granted for certain types of food.
yāgumadhugoḷakānujānana.translation_1: 11. The allowance for congee and honey balls

vighāsādasatāni.meaning_2: consisting of one hundred who eat scraps; a hundred who live on leftovers
vighāsādasatāni.comments: The compound 'vighāsādasata' is a bahuvrīhi compound describing a group of people (a hundred) who live on scraps. The context shows they were following along, likely as ascetics or beggars.
vighāsādasatāni.example_1: “yadā paṭipāṭiṁ labhissāma tadā bhattaṁ karissāmā”ti, pañcamattāni ca vighāsādasatāni.
vighāsādasatāni.translation_1: “When our turn comes, we’ll prepare a meal.” Five hundred people living on scraps were also following along.

gharāvāsattho.meaning_2: household business; domestic affairs; home duties
gharāvāsattho.comments: The word 'gharāvāsattho' is a compound of 'ghara' (house), 'āvāsa' (dwelling), and 'attha' (affairs), referring to the responsibilities and duties associated with maintaining a household. In the given context, it highlights the neglect of domestic duties due to the speaker's preoccupation with following the Sangha.
gharāvāsattho.example_1: “atītāni kho me dve māsāni buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ anubandhantassa ‘yadā paṭipāṭiṁ labhissāmi tadā bhattaṁ karissāmī’ti, na ca me paṭipāṭi labbhati, ahañcamhi ekattako, bahu ca me gharāvāsattho hāyati.
gharāvāsattho.translation_1: “I’ve been following the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for two months waiting to offer them a meal, and I’m still waiting. Moreover, I am all alone, and all my household business is being neglected.
gharāvāsattho.example_2: Na ca me paṭipāṭi labbhati, ahañcamhi ekattako, bahu ca me gharāvāsattho hāyati.

dhotahatthaṃ.meaning_2: with washed hands; with clean hands
dhotahatthaṃ.comments: The compound describes the state of the Buddha after finishing his meal, emphasizing ritual purity by washing hands.
dhotahatthaṃ.example_1: Atha kho so brāhmaṇo buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pahūtāya yāguyā ca madhugoḷakena ca sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā bhagavantaṁ dhotahatthaṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
dhotahatthaṃ.translation_1: That brahmin then personally served much congee and many honey balls to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, the brahmin sat down to one side.
dhotahatthaṃ.example_2: Atha kho keṇiyo jaṭilo buddhappamukhaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pahūtehi pānehi sahatthā santappetvā sampavāretvā bhagavantaṁ dhotahatthaṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
dhotahatthaṃ.translation_2: Keṇiya then personally served that large quantity of drinks to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Keṇiya sat down to one side.

manussasobhagyatamicchatā.meaning_2: desire for human prosperity; wish for fortunate human state
manussasobhagyatamicchatā.comments: The compound combines 'manussa' (human), 'sobhagya' (prosperity), 'taṃ' (that), and 'icchatā' (desire state), forming an abstract noun expressing the desire for human prosperity. The contextual usage suggests a normative or aspirational quality.
manussasobhagyatamicchatā.translation_1: It’s appropriate to give congee regularly.”

taruṇapasannamahāmattavatthu.meaning_2: the case of the government official with recently acquired faith
taruṇapasannamahāmattavatthu.comments: This is a compound word where 'vatthu' is used in the sense of 'case' or 'instance', referring to a story or example, specifically about a government official who has recently acquired faith.
taruṇapasannamahāmattavatthu.translation_1: 12. The government official with recently acquired faith

bhojjayāguṃ.comments: The compound 'bhojjayāgu' is a combination of 'bhojja' (food, to be eaten) and 'yāgu' (rice gruel), referring specifically to edible rice porridge. In the given sentences, it is used in the context of monks being offered or consuming this food.
bhojjayāguṃ.translation_1: they prepared rice porridge and honey balls early in the morning.
bhojjayāguṃ.example_2: “kathañhi nāma bhadantā mayā nimantitā aññassa bhojjayāguṁ paribhuñjissanti, na cāhaṁ paṭibalo yāvadatthaṁ dātun”ti
bhojjayāguṃ.translation_2: “When the venerables have been invited by me, how can they eat someone else’s rice porridge? Am I incapable of giving them as much as they like?”

bhojjayāguyā.comments: The compound 'bhojjayāgu' refers to rice porridge or congee, a staple food mentioned in the context of monks eating it in the morning. It is a combination of 'bhojja' (food) and 'yāgu' (rice gruel).
bhojjayāguyā.example_1: Bhikkhū kālasseva bhojjayāguyā dhātā madhugoḷakena ca bhattagge na cittarūpaṁ paribhuñjanti.
bhojjayāguyā.translation_1: After eating rice porridge and honey balls to their satisfaction in the morning, the monks did not eat as much as they had intended in the dining hall.
bhojjayāguyā.example_2: “Na kho mayaṁ, āvuso, etaṅkāraṇā thokaṁ thokaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma, api ca mayaṁ kālasseva bhojjayāguyā dhātā madhugoḷakena ca. Tena mayaṁ thokaṁ thokaṁ paṭiggaṇhāmā”ti.
bhojjayāguyā.translation_2: “We’re not taking so little because of that, but because we ate rice porridge and honey balls to our satisfaction early in the morning.”

taruṇapasannena.comments: The compound describes a government official who is both young and recently devoted to Buddhism, as seen in the context of inviting the Sangha for a meal.
taruṇapasannena.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarena taruṇapasannena mahāmattena svātanāya buddhappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho nimantito hoti.
taruṇapasannena.translation_1: At this time a certain government official who had recently acquired faith in Buddhism had invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.

taruṇapasannassa.comments: The compound 'taruṇapasanna' combines 'taruṇa' (young) and 'pasanna' (devotee, believer). In the context, it refers to a young official who is a devotee or believer, as seen from his reaction of anxiety and remorse after the Buddha's departure.
taruṇapasannassa.example_1: Atha kho tassa taruṇapasannassa mahāmattassa etadahosi—
taruṇapasannassa.example_2: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa taruṇapasannassa mahāmattassa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi, saddhiṁ bhikkhusaṅghena.
taruṇapasannassa.translation_2: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that brahmin’s house where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.

aḍḍhatelasannaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'aḍḍha' (half) and 'telasa' (thirteen), used here to denote 'twelve and a half' in the context of counting bowls of meat for monks.
aḍḍhatelasannaṃ.example_1: “yannūnāhaṁ aḍḍhatelasannaṁ bhikkhusatānaṁ aḍḍhatelasāni maṁsapātisatāni paṭiyādeyyaṁ, ekamekassa bhikkhuno ekamekaṁ maṁsapātiṁ upanāmeyyan”ti.
aḍḍhatelasannaṃ.translation_1: “Why don’t I prepare twelve hundred and fifty bowls of meat for the twelve hundred and fifty monks? I can then give one bowl to each and every monk.”

maṃsapātisatāni.comments: The compound 'maṃsapātisatāni' refers to a specific quantity of meat bowls (1250 in the context), combining 'maṃsa' (meat), 'pāti' (bowl), and 'sata' (hundred).
maṃsapātisatāni.example_1: “yannūnāhaṁ aḍḍhatelasannaṁ bhikkhusatānaṁ aḍḍhatelasāni maṁsapātisatāni paṭiyādeyyaṁ, ekamekassa bhikkhuno ekamekaṁ maṁsapātiṁ upanāmeyyan”ti.
maṃsapātisatāni.translation_1: “Why don’t I prepare twelve hundred and fifty bowls of meat for the twelve hundred and fifty monks? I can then give one bowl to each and every monk.”
maṃsapātisatāni.example_2: Atha kho so taruṇapasanno mahāmatto tassā rattiyā accayena paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā aḍḍhatelasāni ca maṁsapātisatāni, bhagavato kālaṁ ārocāpesi—“kālo, bhante, niṭṭhitaṁ bhattan”ti.
maṃsapātisatāni.translation_2: The following morning that official had various kinds of fine foods prepared, as well as twelve hundred and fifty bowls of meat. He then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.

maṃsapātiṃ.comments: The compound 'maṃsapāti' is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'maṃsa' (meat) modifies 'pāti' (bowl), indicating a bowl specifically for meat. The context shows it refers to individual portions of meat given to monks.
maṃsapātiṃ.example_1: “yannūnāhaṁ aḍḍhatelasannaṁ bhikkhusatānaṁ aḍḍhatelasāni maṁsapātisatāni paṭiyādeyyaṁ, ekamekassa bhikkhuno ekamekaṁ maṁsapātiṁ upanāmeyyan”ti.
maṃsapātiṃ.translation_1: “Why don’t I prepare twelve hundred and fifty bowls of meat for the twelve hundred and fifty monks? I can then give one bowl to each and every monk.”
maṃsapātiṃ.translation_2: I’ll bring one bowl of meat to each and every one of you.

taruṇapasanno.comments: The word is a compound of 'taruṇa' (young) and 'pasanna' (faithful). In the context, it describes a young official who has recently acquired faith in Buddhism.
taruṇapasanno.example_1: Atha kho so taruṇapasanno mahāmatto tassā rattiyā accayena paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā aḍḍhatelasāni ca maṁsapātisatāni, bhagavato kālaṁ ārocāpesi—“kālo, bhante, niṭṭhitaṁ bhattan”ti.
taruṇapasanno.translation_1: The following morning that official had various kinds of fine foods prepared, as well as twelve hundred and fifty bowls of meat. He then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
taruṇapasanno.example_2: Atha kho so taruṇapasanno mahāmatto bhattagge bhikkhū parivisati.
taruṇapasanno.translation_2: That official then served the monks in the dining hall.

taruṇapasannaṃ.meaning_2: young and devoted; young and faithful
taruṇapasannaṃ.comments: The compound describes the young minister as both young (taruṇa) and devoted/faithful (pasanna), showing his qualities in the context of receiving the Buddha's teaching.
taruṇapasannaṃ.example_1: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho taṁ taruṇapasannaṁ mahāmattaṁ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
taruṇapasannaṃ.translation_1: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.

bhojjayāgu.comments: The compound 'bhojjayāgu' combines 'bhojja' (food, to be eaten) and 'yāgu' (rice gruel), referring specifically to rice porridge as a staple food item. In the given context, it refers to a meal that should not be consumed when one has already been invited to another meal, highlighting monastic etiquette.
bhojjayāgu.example_1: “na, bhikkhave, aññatra nimantitena aññassa bhojjayāgu paribhuñjitabbā.
bhojjayāgu.translation_1: “When you have been invited to a meal, you shouldn’t eat someone else’s rice porridge beforehand.

guḷakumbhapūrehi.meaning_2: filled with jars of sugar; stuffed with sugar pots
guḷakumbhapūrehi.comments: The compound 'guḷakumbhapūrehi' is a bahubbīhi (possessive) compound, describing the carts as being filled with jars of sugar. The context clearly shows that 'guḷa' refers to sugar (meaning_3), 'kumbha' to jars (meaning_1), and 'pūra' to being filled (adj from pūrati). The instrumental plural ending '-ehi' indicates the means by which the carts are filled.
guḷakumbhapūrehi.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena belaṭṭho kaccāno rājagahā andhakavindaṁ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti, pañcamattehi sakaṭasatehi, sabbeheva guḷakumbhapūrehi.
guḷakumbhapūrehi.translation_1: Just then Belaṭṭha Kaccāna was traveling from Rājagaha to Andhakavinda with five hundred carts, all of them filled with jars of sugar.

guḷakumbhaṃ.comments: The compound 'guḷakumbha' is a tatpurusa (determinative) compound where 'guḷa' (sugar) modifies 'kumbha' (jar). The context clearly shows it refers to a jar containing sugar, hence 'jar of sugar' is the most accurate meaning here.
guḷakumbhaṃ.example_1: “icchāmahaṁ, bhante, ekamekassa bhikkhuno ekamekaṁ guḷakumbhaṁ dātun”ti.
guḷakumbhaṃ.translation_1: “Sir, I would like to give one jar of sugar to each and every monk.”
guḷakumbhaṃ.example_2: “Tena hi tvaṁ, kaccāna, ekaṁyeva guḷakumbhaṁ āharā”ti.
guḷakumbhaṃ.translation_2: “Well then, Kaccāna, just bring one jar of sugar.”

guḷakumbho.meaning_2: jar of sugar; jar of molasses; sugar jar
guḷakumbho.comments: The compound 'guḷakumbha' combines 'guḷa' (sugar/molasses) with 'kumbha' (jar/pot), referring to a jar containing sugar or molasses. The context suggests a container for a sweet substance, likely used in offerings or daily life.

belaṭṭhassa.comments: The word 'belaṭṭhassa' is the dative singular form of 'belaṭṭha', referring to the monk Belaṭṭha Kaccāna. The context shows it as a proper noun, the name of an arahant monk who received teachings from the Buddha.
belaṭṭhassa.example_1: Ekamantaṁ nisinnassa kho belaṭṭhassa kaccānassa bhagavā anupubbiṁ kathaṁ kathesi, seyyathidaṁ—
belaṭṭhassa.translation_1: The Buddha then gave him a progressive talk—
belaṭṭhassa.example_2: evameva belaṭṭhassa kaccānassa tasmiṁyeva āsane virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi—
belaṭṭhassa.translation_2: And just as a clean and stainless cloth absorbs dye properly, so too, while he was sitting right there, Belaṭṭha Kaccāna experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:

pāṭaligāmavatthu.meaning_2: the case of Pāṭaligāma; the story of Pāṭaligāma; the grounds of Pāṭaligāma
pāṭaligāmavatthu.comments: The compound refers to a narrative or case related to the village of Pāṭaligāma, likely detailing events or teachings associated with it.
